Problem:
Consider a heat equation \\(u_t = \\kappa \\Delta u\\) where \\(\\kappa\\) is the heat conductivity coefficient, and \\(\\Delta\\) is the Laplacian operator. Let's analyze the introduction of an external heat source \\(h(x, t)\\), which varies over time and space, via the modification of the equation to \\(u_t = \\kappa \\Delta u + h(x, t)\\).

If an intervention by changing the conductivity coefficient \\(\\kappa\\) to a different value \\(\\kappa'\\) is made at time \\(t_1\\), will the heat distribution \\(u(x, T)\\) where \\(T > t_1\\) depend solely on the new conductivity \\(\\kappa'\\) and ignore the previous \\(\\kappa\\) values and \\(h(x, t)\\) values applied?
Explanation: The transient effects and the previously applied heat source \\(h(x, t)\\) alongside changes in conductivity affect how heat spreads and accumulates, impacting the end temperature distribution not just based on the current value \\(\\kappa'\\) but also past influences.
